0.12.text: Abby Martin is an internationally known journalist

2.49.text: who hosted the no-holds-barred ‘Breaking the Set’ on Russia Today.

6.70.text: She currently writes and directs a weekly documentary series called The Empire Files,

13.11.text: She founded her own media organization, Media Roots,

16.27.text: and sits on the board of Project Censored,

18.54.text: one of the largest research groups in the country.

20.82.text: Abby’s empathy, passion and editorial independence makes her

24.23.text: a unique and relatable voice to those seeking honest independent media.

35.32.text: Thank you so much everyone for that, and

38.65.text: first of all, thank you so much for The Venus Project

41.02.text: for hosting me at this amazing event.

43.33.text: And happy birthday to visionary Jacque Fresco.

53.80.text: This is a man who has spent his entire life

56.74.text: innovating for a better world, and I think

58.58.text: we need to give him one more round of applause, for that!

103.38.text: It’s a total honor to be asked to speak at your centennial celebration,

108.40.text: And it's great to meet so many people here who

110.65.text: already know my work from Russia Today, 'Breaking the Set.'

114.76.text: My new show on teleSUR is a little different. It’s a little bit

117.83.text: less energy, but a little bit more depressing, maybe.

121.96.text: It's called the Empire Files; it’s on teleSUR English and

125.15.text: it's a weekly documentary series that

127.62.text: provides crucial historical and political context

129.86.text: to the most pressing issues that we face today,

131.88.text: which I think is really important

133.71.text: when we're looking at these issues in an isolated context,

136.69.text: especially reacting to the mainstream media 24-hour news cycle.

140.91.text: From the alliance with the brutal Saudi theocracy

143.58.text: to the US funding death squads across Latin America,

146.17.text: each chapter of the Empire Files really lays bare

148.75.text: another devastating effect of militaristic imperialism.

152.56.text: So definitely check it out, if you haven’t yet! on YouTube. Thank you.

163.90.text: because they are very acutely aware already

165.94.text: of the crisis of civilization that we face.

168.89.text: But I want to read a breathtaking statistic that I think really exemplifies

172.50.text: EVERYthing that’s wrong with the world we live in today.

175.46.text: According to the latest Oxfam study,

182.60.text: than half of everybody living on the planet.

184.76.text: Think about that statistic for one second.

190.21.text: own more than half the world’s population!

193.88.text: The gap between the rich and poor is widening at an alarming rate.

198.09.text: The wealth of the poorest half, 3.6 billion people,

201.06.text: has fallen by $1 trillion dollars since 2010.

205.03.text: And at the same time, the wealth of the world’s richest 62

208.96.text: lucky mother fuckers has increased by more than half a trillion dollars!

214.99.text: This OBSCENE trajectory proves that when people make more money,

221.60.text: Instead, untaxed trillions sit hoarded offshore.

226.63.text: In the US, for the first time in over 50 years,

229.85.text: over half of public school students

232.49.text: are living in poverty or are food insecure.

237.13.text: I mean, how are teachers supposed to meet standardized testing requirements

240.67.text: when they’re busy worrying about whether or not their students are eating food,

246.32.text: Instead of organizing to help those most in need,

248.78.text: our ruthless system criminalizes poverty and homelessness,

253.43.text: the extreme consequences of which are playing out all around us,

257.40.text: driving desperate people to commit violence,

262.97.text: This growing dysfunction is built into an economic structure

270.68.text: But it’s not just a system in the abstract.

273.09.text: This global order installs powerful rulers.

276.59.text: I saw the way it works firsthand, throughout my career.

280.36.text: I didn’t start out wanting to be a journalist.

283.59.text: I began as an anti-war activist and organizer in college

286.41.text: during the lead-up to the Iraq war.

289.84.text: But I quickly saw the issues I was rallying behind were either

292.22.text: being distorted or completely ignored in the media.

295.86.text: And witnessing the media’s complete obedience

298.30.text: to the criminal, murderous policies of the Bush administration,

301.50.text: propelled me, forced me to act.

304.46.text: I taught myself video production and just put myself out there

307.24.text: in the community, first San Diego and then Oakland,

309.88.text: the first citizen journalism project that I founded called Media Roots.

313.67.text: And it wasn’t just one issue. It was every issue,

316.70.text: because it all stems from the same criminal corrupt system.

320.27.text: From net neutrality to food justice, I wanted to build upon an

323.71.text: under-reported aggregate of stories that impacted everyone,

327.94.text: because I was convinced if people only knew what was happening!

330.96.text: If they only knew what this government was doing around the world,

333.43.text: then of course, they would organize to stop it.

336.66.text: But, informing the masses in today’s world is a daunting challenge,

342.36.text: It doesn’t take long in your political awakening to realize

344.89.text: that the establishment press we’ve all been trained to trust,

348.49.text: exists as just another arm of the corporatocracy,

354.31.text: Didn’t start off that way, it started out as a free public service.

358.31.text: But as the corporatocracy became more entrenched,

361.01.text: telecomm companies got hugely rich off profiting

364.04.text: the free utility of public air waves,

366.25.text: and begin tightening their grip on the market,

368.80.text: eating each other up, just as we’ve seen in every other industry.

377.91.text: By 1992, that number shrunk to 2 dozen.

386.05.text: of everything Americans see, hear, and read.

388.76.text: About 120 or so executives on the boards of these 6 companies

393.22.text: also have interlocking positions in every industry

395.55.text: from defense to pharmaceuticals ... to banking.

399.64.text: Aside from this blatant conflict of interest lies the problem of self-censorship

403.89.text: and advertising pressure within these networks.

407.33.text: Right now, who has heard of the TPP?

410.07.text: I am sure many people. Okay, good job.

413.50.text: But, of course, this hugely important so-called free trade deal -

416.74.text: which people are calling NAFTA on steroids - between 12 countries

419.98.text: that will completely eviscerate national sovereignty and undermine US laws!! ...

424.02.text: totally blacked out! 100%, on the mainstream media. Why?

429.12.text: Well, their corporate sponsors are among those negotiating the secret deal.

432.66.text: 600 corporate advisers negotiating this deal between 12 countries,

436.70.text: without any sort of semblance of democratic participation from the people.

442.24.text: Net neutrality, another important issue of our time,

444.45.text: maintaining the egalitarian nature of the web,

448.83.text: by the same media companies controlled by massive telecommunications companies,

452.97.text: the same companies that are trying to install a pay-to-play network on the Internet.

459.02.text: Many people around the world may be wondering

462.47.text: how a reality-star billionaire, with zero political experience

466.20.text: is this close to becoming the president of the United States of America,

471.89.text: But I think a quick scan of our ad-infested click-bait media

482.21.text: IS WHO LEGITIMIZED Donald Trump! by covering him 24/7,

494.17.text: Trump has been given more media coverage than

496.49.text: ALL Democratic campaigns combined, 23 times more than Bernie Sanders!

504.30.text: CBS head Les Moonves actually recently boasted about this.

508.50.text: He said “Trump may not be good for America,

511.84.text: but it’s damn good for CBS.

514.52.text: The money's rolling in, and this is fun.

518.34.text: It's going to be a very good year for us. Sorry,

521.88.text: it's a terrible thing to say. But bring it on Donald. Keep going.”

526.90.text: The media may understand the consequences of promoting Trump’s

529.90.text: xenophobic bigotry. But the short term profits for companies like CBS,

534.97.text: far outweigh the dangers of a Trump presidency.

538.83.text: The corporate takeover of the Fourth Estate has disemboweled

542.17.text: any semblance of a democracy in this country.

545.83.text: For decades, journalists in DC have cared far more about their access,

552.73.text: I saw this first hand in DC when I was actually scolded

556.22.text: by media officials for asking questions unsolicited to Rand Paul in Congress.

561.24.text: When I first was a newbie,

563.27.text: I got my official press badge, and I was like

565.62.text: “Cool, now I can just go ask and confront politicians in the halls of the Congress.”

569.51.text: And very quickly, the first person I saw walking down the hall was Rand Paul,

574.58.text: and I asked him a question: I said “Why did you endorse Mitt Romney?”

577.61.text: He ignored me, kept going; I thought that was the end of it.

579.80.text: A week later, RT started getting calls from the Congress press bureau,

585.06.text: threatening to arrest me for stalking and harassment.

588.24.text: Mm-hmm! I wanted to put it on air, they didn’t want to because they,

591.72.text: they were really catering to the Ron Paul audience at that time,

594.31.text: and I was really new and I didn’t really know what to do.

597.38.text: The charges were all basically empty threats.

600.80.text: But they did call me into the office, and I sat down in an interrogation room

604.16.text: in the halls of Congress, with all the main bureau chief heads,

607.14.text: from the corporate media networks, and they basically told me

609.87.text: “You don’t do that. You don’t come in here,

612.90.text: and ruin our access that we've worked for decades to maintain.”

617.45.text: And that was my first lesson of how journalism actually worked in DC.

621.47.text: You know, the media doesn’t only work to protect its bottom line.

624.91.text: It also plays a key role in manufacturing consent for Empire.

628.89.text: Conditioning us to believe that somehow because we’re born

631.97.text: within a particular landmass that we’re ordained to go kill

635.10.text: millions of people around the world.

637.29.text: Displace and maim, countless millions more.

642.99.text: for tens of millions, if not hundreds of millions of people,

649.08.text: Even so-called alternative press outlets like Vice and others,

652.25.text: promote US Empire and American exceptionalism;

654.52.text: these are very dangerous notions that keep society subservient.

659.18.text: The myths also justify untold criminal policies

662.34.text: by rationalizing a war economy that runs on death and destruction.

667.27.text: Those in power have a lot of reasons to control the narrative, of course,

671.72.text: the long list of injustices and crimes they carry out every day,

675.72.text: but to conceal the cataclysmic course they’re driving us down.

681.82.text: Those in power don’t just control the media, of course,

685.02.text: they control our energy resources too.

688.84.text: Under this system, the US continues to rely on an industry

691.94.text: that imperils all life on Earth.

695.11.text: According to the latest UN report,

696.86.text: in order to avoid the worst predicted effects of climate change,

700.74.text: 3/4 of known existing fossil fuels need to stay in the ground.

705.40.text: That means halting all production, stopping, right now!

709.38.text: And that’s to avoid the worst effects! the worst effects.

712.86.text: But the empire is doing the opposite of that:

718.06.text: Under Obama, the US has become the world’s largest

721.39.text: oil and natural gas producer. That’s astounding!

724.84.text: The US military is the biggest polluter on the planet,

728.64.text: yet exempt from all environmental legislation,

730.92.text: from the Clean Air Act to the Kyoto treaty.

734.65.text: With all interrogation about how the richest country in the world

737.82.text: could POSSIBLY pay for health care and education for its citizens,

744.02.text: about how we can possibly afford to maintain endless war, occupation,

747.70.text: as well as a military budget that stands bigger than the next 7 countries combined.

752.01.text: If this system put the needs of the people and the environment first,

755.91.text: there would be very little dependency on such a damaging fuel source.

760.13.text: Stanford engineers, as you’ve seen in the documentary this morning,

762.63.text: have already developed a cost-effective state-by-state plan to transition

766.74.text: the entire US to renewable energy sources by 2050!

771.68.text: The money spent on the Iraq war alone,

779.61.text: planted the seeds for ISIS to flourish,

782.58.text: could have covered all global investments to halt

786.49.text: climate change trends. Think about that!

790.27.text: The Iraq war could have halted all global climate change trends,

795.20.text: There’s plenty of money to solve humanity’s pressing problems.

798.73.text: The issue isn't resources; it’s how they’re being used.

803.58.text: You know, as much as Cuba is criticized,

805.86.text: it’s never hailed for its achievements.

808.47.text: I was able to spend weeks there,

810.46.text: reporting and found it fascinating that, under a crippling economic embargo,

814.70.text: this small island nation was still able to produce

818.05.text: standards of living comparable to most European countries.

821.24.text: High-quality free education, high-quality free health care, a home and more,

827.86.text: Not to mention a completely green sustainable agricultural system.

834.54.text: Cuba’s crime rate is one of the lowest in the entire hemisphere's.

838.67.text: Oddly enough, it seems that when people have their basic human needs met,

842.18.text: they're less likely to commit crimes.

846.78.text: I mean, you know, these resounding accomplishments were made

850.46.text: in an economy based on scarcity.

852.73.text: Imagine what can be done in the richest country in the world! ...

856.36.text: ... if people came first, not profits.

860.45.text: The continued success of any nation bucking the global economic order,

864.41.text: even a small island-nation like Cuba,

866.69.text: poses a huge, huge threat to corporate hegemony.

870.33.text: This is why, despite this “normalization” process,

872.98.text: the US government is still spending countless millions on the ground for regime change there.

877.84.text: We’ve seen how far the empire will go,

880.46.text: to crush any and all alternatives.

884.93.text: Those in power also wield the most massive military in human history,

888.94.text: to wage a very real war on ideas

891.75.text: that provide an alternative to their system,

894.17.text: both abroad and here at home.

896.76.text: Over the last century, the US government has done everything in its power

900.04.text: to snuff out alternatives to its rule,

902.98.text: from roundups to mass arrests of thousands of anarchists,

909.18.text: making it illegal to even be a communist,

912.48.text: to carrying out military interventions in over 70 nations

918.31.text: causing untold human misery, all in the name of fighting ideas.

923.78.text: Today, the US Empire has at least 900 military installations around the world;

928.13.text: the Pentagon doesn’t even know, because of how many lily pad bases they have,

933.74.text: They have troops stationed in almost every region of the world

935.94.text: to maintain endless war and occupation.

938.83.text: But as daunting as all of this is,

943.96.text: a glitch in the matrix provides a rare political opening for us.

950.07.text: Those in power have also rigged elections, obviously,

952.92.text: from the Electoral College, the delegate process,

955.16.text: to the omission of third parties from the debates.

958.00.text: But Bernie Sanders has defied all odds,

960.34.text: because he’s bringing the message of Occupy Wall Street,

963.00.text: a movement completely ridiculed and marginalized in the mainstream,

968.94.text: ... to the entire nation. His popularity-…

973.14.text: He’s made it okay to criticize capitalism!

977.90.text: For all the critiques on Bernie Sander’s foreign policy, etc., look:

981.86.text: His popularity is opening a path for us to criticize the system,

986.38.text: when just 5 years ago, it was unheard of. This is a huge thing for us now.

990.70.text: According to a recent Pew poll,

992.35.text: young people between the ages of 18 and 29,

996.27.text: more favorably look at socialism than they do capitalism.

1002.15.text: against a relentless propaganda campaign that’s existed for almost a century.

1007.48.text: The two party dictatorship is unraveling, fast.

1011.72.text: Having voters reject the candidates that the establishment is literally

1015.13.text: begging them to accept, is amazing.

1018.10.text: Only good things can come from the corporate duopoly splintering like this.

1023.49.text: Those in power have an end game.

1029.38.text: And right now there's a huge opportunity for change.

1035.86.text: And the voices in this room have so much potential to be heard, right now.

1040.93.text: It’s time to seize the momentum,

1042.95.text: start building the utopia we wish to see.

1046.50.text: Because in the words of Jacque Fresco,

1048.48.text: “If you think we can’t change the world,

1051.37.text: it just means you're one of the ones that won’t.”
